QUESTION:
Will the new Prime Minister of Iceland belong to the Left-Green Movement after the 2024 parliamentary elections?

TODAY'S DATE:
2024-11-11

RESOLUTION CRITERIA:
This question will resolve **Yes** if the new prime minister belongs to the Left-Green Movement at the time of receiving the mandate to form a government by the President.

If, for any reason, no one has received the mandate before 1 January 2025 (including that the election is postponed or the coalition talks are ongoing), this question will resolve as **No**.

BACKGROUND:
The [2017 parliamentary elections in Iceland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_Icelandic_parliamentary_election) resulted in an unusual governing coalition of the left-wing [Left-Green Movement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Left-Green_Movement), the centre [Progressive Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Progressive_Party_(Iceland)), and the centre-right [Independence Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independence_Party_(Iceland)). Despite the Independence Party being the largest party in the coalition, the new prime minister was [Katrín Jakobsdóttir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katr%C3%ADn_Jakobsd%C3%B3ttir), the chairperson of the Left-Green Movement.

In [2021](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Icelandic_parliamentary_election), the three-party coalition maintained its majority and remained governmend under the lead of Katrín Jakobsdóttir. However, Jakobsdóttir resigned in April 2024 to contest the [presidential election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Icelandic_presidential_election), which she lost. She was succeeded as prime minister by [Bjarni Benediktsson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bjarni_Benediktsson_(born_1970)), the leader of the Independence Party, who had previously been the prime minister in 2017 and who was the Minister of Finance and Economic Affairs of the current government.

On 13 October, Benediktsson [announced](https://apnews.com/article/iceland-snap-election-coalition-government-9d170f37de3228506de93444668c416a) that the government had collapsed due to disputes over foreign policy, asylum seekers, and energy, prompting him to call for new elections and ask President Halla Tómasdóttir the next day to dissolve the Althingi and set the elections for 30 November.

ADDITIONAL BACKGROUND:
Based on the current information, it is highly unlikely that the new Prime Minister of Iceland will belong to the Left-Green Movement after the 2024 parliamentary elections. Here are some key points that support this assessment:

## Current Popularity of the Left-Green Movement
The Left-Green Movement is currently experiencing significant declines in popularity. According to recent polls, the party's support has dropped to just 2.4%, which is one of the lowest levels among the major parties in Iceland[4].

## Coalition Collapse and Political Climate
The coalition government, which included the Left-Green Movement, collapsed due to disagreements on various policy issues. This collapse and the subsequent call for snap elections in November indicate a lack of cohesion and vision within the coalition, further weakening the Left-Green Movement's position[3][5].

## Leadership and Public Support
Svandís Svavarsdóttir, the chairman of the Left-Green Movement, has stated that the party's MPs will not participate in the acting government, and the party is focusing on the upcoming elections. However, the party's support has not shown any significant signs of recovery since Svavarsdóttir took over[2][4].

## Opposition and Other Parties' Popularity
Other parties, particularly the Social Democratic Alliance, the Centre Party, and the Liberal Reform Party, are currently more popular and have higher levels of support. The Social Democratic Alliance, for example, has the most support with over 24%[4].

Given these factors, it is clear that the Left-Green Movement faces significant challenges in regaining enough support to lead the government after the 2024 parliamentary elections. Therefore, the likelihood of the new Prime Minister belonging to the Left-Green Movement is very low.
